Reviews.Title: Great trail cam
Reviews.Author: Northwoodsman
Reviews.Content: I have owned several diffferent trail cams over the past 5 years.  Some good, some just fair, some bad. The battery life and the fire up response time to take a picture is very important.  I recently purchased 2 of these bushnell trail cams.  Both the battery life and the response time for the Bushnell are excellent.  Battery life is awesome, and the trigger time is so quick I rarely miss a picture.  I can honestly say this is the best trail cam I have ever owned.

Reviews.Title: Pleased in East Texas
Reviews.Author: Scott G Bryk
Reviews.Content: I received this product and am very pleased.  I've had a lot of luck with these small Bushnell cameras.  Battery life is great and trigger speed is also quite good.  For clarification, this IS the 2011 model with the field scan.  Up to 8 Meg images.  My only semi negative feedback would be that with field scan you can only set one time period, so if you are going to take images during the morning and evening periods you basically have to include the entire day or the entire night.  The entire night would definitely wear down the batteries (IR flash).  I imagine it is a simple software fix that Bushnell will put out in the future.  I own Moultries at the same price point and far prefer my Bushnells.  I simply can't choke out the cash for the Reconyx cameras.  They are entirely too pricey to have a sufficient quantity of them to try to understand the deer herd on the size property where I hunt.  I can get five Bushnells for the price of two Reconyx.  My Bushnell from last season stood the outdoor life well here in East TX (heat, rain, heat, rain...).I also bought the python lock and metal outside case...  they're kind of a pain in the rear to deal with (I'm a low irritant tolerant guy) and nothing a bolt cutter wouldn't make quick work of.  Probably not worth it unless hunting public land.Finally I searched the web pretty heavily and found the price at Amazon was the best I could do.  If you can beat it though, congrats, then I'm the chump.Regardless, I'm happy you're reading this because it means you're also excited about deer season.  God blessed this great land and you too, be safe and happy scouting!SGB

Reviews.Title: Excellent for hunting, not so much for surveillance (mod 119436C)
Reviews.Author: J. Smith
Reviews.Content: First, this review is for the 119436C model.I bought this camera for surveillance at my business (kind of a bridge-the-gap measure until I can get an effective surveillance system installed.)  The camera takes good color pics in the daylight, and good black and white pics at night.  The consistently effective range of this is around 50 feet, with occasional pick ups at 80 feet.  Part of the reason for this is most likely the clean background area, anything moving through the area is "framed" by dirt, no moving bushes or background noise that will cause false triggers or interference.The pictures are good, but I have noticed some slight distortion away from the center of the pictures, a slight fish eye effect.My main problem with this unit is that the led's do glow a noticeable red color which is pretty noticeable in dark environments.  The flash catches the eye kind of like something flitting by.  I plan to move this unit to a more lit area to compare the flash glow and see if it is still as noticeable.I rate this at 5 stars in spite of my led visibility because this camera is designed for game images and videos.  It was not designed to be a business surveillance tool, I just wanted to list the drawbacks of this unit for those who might be considering it for the same purpose.Edit to add:  I moved this unit to a more lit location and it does help with the glow noticeability, but it is still there.  I purchased the Bushnell Black LED trail camera (# 119466C) and am more pleased with the flash performance.  The LED glow is almost nonexistent in pitch black conditions on the black led camera.

Reviews.Title: 2011 Model - Best trailcam on the market
Reviews.Author: JP Vic "Bee Guy"
Reviews.Content: II have three trailcams from Bushnell, two earlier models and this new one.  This one is the 2011 model that has audio (not really important), a timer to take a picture (field scan), and can handle 32GB memory cards.I also own three other trail cams from Moultrie a M-60, I-40 and a D-50.  I had a cuddleback two years ago, and it worked fine, but it got destroyed (tree fell on it).  I do not own the new Moultrie M-100, which seems very similar to this Bushnell, but this is the first year for the M-100 and I bet they will have software issues.  This is the 3rd year for Bushnell and they have this camera dialed-in very well.The biggest issue with my older Moultrie cams is battery life.  They need feed 6 D cells about once a month.  The price of the batteries start to add up, but mostly the issue is going out to a dead trailcam and wondering what pictures you missed.  A battery life of 1-year for just 8 AA is great.Aside from battery life, all these trailcams seem to do the work well.  Basically I want to take a picture of game when it walks by and they all do that.  I'm not going to publish my pictures in National Geographic, I mostly want to count horns and find patterns.  All do that just fine for me.I've stuck different models of trail cams on the same tree and compared results.  It's weird, sometimes the Bushnell shoots and sometimes the Moultrie shoots but most of the time they both shoot when game walks by.I like the 2 year warranty from Bushnell and have used it.  The first year model had issues, and I returned it- they then sent me a new current year model.  I had issues with a Moltrie cam once and tried to get warranty work, but they did not honor the warranty and returned my camera.  I bought from an on-line dealer they did not like.  ( I will only buy from major retailers now)I do like the nighttime flash color pictures from my Moultrie D-50, as it is nice to see in color.  All nighttime trailcams that use IR flash come out in black and white.  Flash vs IR is a personal thing, but in the end I'm counting horns and B&W; is fine for my needs.The biggest thing I hate about the I-40 &M-60; Moultrie is the fact that it is not easy to swap the SD card.  I sometimes like to check my cams every day and it's a real pain to swap SD cards.  On the Bushnell it's a piece of cake.The biggest thing I hate about the Bushnell is that programming in the field under low light conditions is difficult.  The screen is hard to read and the buttons are impossible.  I find I need a small flashlight unless it is a bright sunny day.Some trailcams come with a `viewer'.  Personally I think it is a waste, save your money.  If you need to view pics in the field, most all cameras (the cameras you use to take pictures of the kids) that use a SD chip will display trailcams pics,  and so do smartphones.  In my trailcams I use microSD with an adaptor and then plug the microSD into my blackberry for field viewing (If I can't wait to get back to the house).Summary, I've been real happy with my Bushnell trailcam.  I buy one new cam every year and for 2011 bought this one.  I did look at the Moultrie M-100 and I think it would have worked fine for my needs, but it was a bit more $$ than the Bushnell and the fact that the Moultrie is a first year model made me stay with the Bushnell this year.

Reviews.Title: Great little camera
Reviews.Author: Georgejr
Reviews.Content: Picked up this unit based on good reviews and a great warranty. Comes with free software to scan thru 1000's of pics to find motion (great when using field scan mode) and comes with free software for a buck scoring software (I haven't used this yet).  The Scouting assistant software is great tool.  Currently I have it set to 5MP, 1 sec delay, high sensitivity, Field scan turned on for 6am thru 7:15pm.  After being on for just over a week used about 1 GB with these settings.First location was in the middle of woods in a thick tall grass trail.  Worked great facing NW direction.  Plenty of canopy so I wasn't worried about direct sun.  New spot is facing direct N (most state this is best if you can face north to avoid direct sun wash-out of the pics).  At our house I tested (I highly recommend this to get used to the camera) facing south and south west w/o any problems with only 2 trees in our yard.  Took great pics of cars and people in the neighborhood.  I did have some low light blurring of pics till I updated the firmware as noted below.I would recommend the following.  Sony Envelope rechargeable batteries (new ones have even more charge cycles and have great life (85% of capacity after a year  and spend a few bucks on the BC-700 Lacrosse charger or something similar.  This charger took my Energizer rechargeable and gave them new life.  Charges each cell separately and doesn't rely on just a timer. Our Digital camera went from 3 weeks between trying to take a pic and having dead batteries to lasting 4-6 months with about the same amount of use.  Old energizer charger cooked the batteries I am guessing and the storage life was non existent, new charger they are working much better, but do loose over time so I would not use with this camera due its low consumptions and possible to go seasons on 1 charge.Just ordered a 16 GB memory card and plan on trying videos later this fall to watch turkey patterns (Time lapse and Trigger can be set to use video, you get either pics or video but you can't do one of each).  I purchased a Scandisk class 4 and MicroSD size so I can also view on my phone (Micro to SD adapter used in the unit).  Class 4 card is probably over-kill but the price was not much different then class 2 (Higher is faster  Be careful of fake memory cards, If you write a review make sure to know the seller if you are sure it was not a fake.  Amazon has frustration free on the MicroSD and you can be assured it is not fake.  I've read several reviews where memory cards were the problem or low battery life was tied to it on this and other trail cams.Note Bushnell has a 2010 and 2011 firmware update.  Review your Ser # to see if you need to update it.  Fixed blurry pics I had in night vision before I ran the update.************  Update OCT 5th 2012:  Camera going strong and what a great tool.  I've been just using only motion this fall so far (corn still on fields so I will wait to use time lapse to track turkeys at a distance for late fall turkeys.  I've found mounting the camera higher on the tree and angling down (I use parts of branches but you could saw a few wood shims too) works great for night shots to avoid triggering camera and only seeing eyes of deer out past 50 yrds.  I did this really to make sure bucks don't try to rub camera but found the additional nice feature, as gun deer gets closer I will mount lower and on a tree overlooking a field to track as much activity as I can.  Right now just want good pics of deer within 40 yrds.  If you want to see these shots keep the camera 6' or less height, but I'm at 9 ft angled down using a ratchet tie down to hold camera and getting great pics including a 8 min fight on a huge buck and nice mature buck.  I use a gator and stand on the bed to swap cards and if needed batteries.  I tend to swap batteries when I see one bar on set-up as I have found these rechargeables do last a long time.  I have it set to take 3 pics at each trigger and 1 sec between shots so I get a old time video which is great to watch each camera shot (Camera has video but I still haven't used it yet as I can go months between getting out to the camera the 3 pics / trigger allows me to see enough info on where they are going and what they are doing).  I've had over 9,000 shots on one set of the rechargeables and on a 16 GB card which had space to spare yet.  It was still taking shots which was due in part to time lapse mode taking most during the day I was using in the spring to pattern turkeys (LOVE this feature).  I have now purchased a second set of rechargeables and a second memory card to make swapping out easier.  I would note to be careful changing batteries as I have dropped one on two occasions and often I am swapping late at night which can make finding the battery a bit difficult.  I have found them but use one hand to push and pop battery and your other hand to cover bottom of box incase they don't stay in your hand.  I find if I miss them they hit the bottom of the camera box and down they go.

Reviews.Title: PERFECT for BACKYARD WILDLIFE SURVEILLANCE
Reviews.Author: StopBreedingParrots "Rescue A Pet"

} } } Length:: 0:38 MinsVIDEO of a TINY MOUSE (taken in Summer 2011 on the far SW Side of Chicago): The Bushnell Hunt Cam was set up on a tripod and caught this litte mouse snooping around the back of the neighbor's garage during the night. I prefer taking videos to see which way my nightly visitors go and how they behave. I've increased the length of the videos to 35-40 seconds which does eat into battery life a bit. I have the cam set on high sensitivity and, on that setting, the Bushnell has picked up critters as small as this mouse in addition to raccoons, a possum, cats, chipmunks, birds and squirrels (during the day). Daytime videos could be a bit less grainy, sound could use some improvement and there is no moon phase or temperature stamp, only date & time. However, the camera takes FANTASTIC photos (I posted some at the top of the page when I had the camera set up to monitor the taking down of our huge old maple tree that carpenter ants had entirely hollowed out).My main reasons for deciding on the Bushnell were that it can be set up on a tripod to move around easily to different areas of the yard, that it has sound and that it picks up tiny creatures which a lot of the others do NOT (I tested others next to the Bushnell and they failed the small animal test)! So, I'm very happy with this hunt cam for my purpose of seeing who snoops thru my yard at night!!! :>)NOTE re the VIDEO: Use FULL screen when watching the video -- the mouse is so tiny. Also, when it disappears behind the garage for a second, it comes right back.The Bushnell was about 4-6 feet from the mouse and approx. a foot off the ground.

Reviews.Title: outstanding
Reviews.Author: A Customer
Reviews.Content: best game camera i've owned.  made my own base for it and set up in tree about 20 feet. takes awesome photos. very clear. use 4g sd card that holds lots of photos.  would buy this again. battery life great. had a moultrie before, did not like.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: Elsen
Reviews.Content: This is the 4th bushnell trohpy cam I own.  I will continue to purchase them over and over.Pros:Fantastic Battery Life - I use Energizer ultimate lithium batteries with these cameras.  I am able to get tens of thousands of pictures on a single set (somewhere between 15k and 20k)Captures all game - Its IR sensor is actually set wider than the camera lens.  Because of this the camera seems to capture most game.  This has one negative though, it can produce a  few blank pictures.  Digital pictures are almost free though (battery life I guess costs), so who cares?Warranty - 2 Years, find another camera that does this.  I had ants get into one of my cameras via the battery cable slot.  They made it inoperable.  I sent the camera in to be repaired.  22 days after sending it in, I received a brand new camera.  The camera was the newer model.Cons:Have to tape the battery cable cover shut so ants do not get in.Blurred pictures - I have found that some of the pictures are blurred.  I am on the latest software update.

Reviews.Title: Eye on the trail
Reviews.Author: Dorena Mountain Man
Reviews.Content: It took some experimentation to find the best location to place the Trophy Cam, but that's half the fun.I knew there was lot of activity from all the well used trails but actually seeing what was making thosetrails was another thing.  So far, about 3 weeks, I have photos of deer, elk, cougar and a few thingsthat no one has been able to identify.I may get one or two more of these game cameras to cover other areas of my property.  These othercameras will have the ability to view images on the LCD screen.  The camera I'm reviewing does nothave that feature.  I have to bring my i-Pad with me and plug in the card.  This is OK if it's not storming.

Reviews.Title: Best Trail Cam Available
Reviews.Author: Marcus Jahna
Reviews.Content: I've had one of these cameras for over a year and I just bought two more because they work so well. Takes great pictures during all times of the day and the batteries have lasted me a whole season, over 4000 photos easily. I would recommend this camera to anyone who is considering it. One of the nicest things about it is that it is compact and rugged.

Reviews.Title: Not perfect, but still really happy
Reviews.Author: D. Burke
Reviews.Content: I bought this trail cam to monitor a feral cat colony that I manage.  I wanted to see how many cats were coming to the feeding station that still needed to be neutered/spayed.I've only used it the last two nights, and I did get a lot of great videos.On the SD card this morning, there were 55 videos, and over half of them were false triggers and just videos of the food bowl with no animals - I do have it set on high sensitivity, and I think the neighbor's hanging flower basket might have been setting it off.I was also missing images of cats that I knew for a fact had come by, but the camera had not picked them up.One thing to mention, in night vision mode, I can't tell apart the orange and white cats.  The black and white images make them look all white.  What I CAN see in night vision mode, however, is if the cats are ear-tipped (the clinic clips the tip of their left ear when they neuter so you can quickly tell).when the night vision is triggered, you can see red glowing from the LEDs, so if you want a spy cam, get one of the others.  For my use, the red is fine.I haven't tried the still mode yet, just the video mode.  I'll edit my review later when I play with the settings some more.The description says that the batteries last up to a year.  I'm assuming that this is for still photos only.  I had the video length set to 60 seconds, and the sensitivity on the motion detection to "high" and I got about and hour a night of moths flying by, and the batteries only lasted 3 days (I only had 4, not 8 at the time).  The thing started acting up, too, and fresh batteries made it work fine. I've adjusted my settings, and now the batteries are lasting a little bit longer.Edit:I've attempted the still picture mode several times, and it doesn't seem to work right.  I got one picture of my husband walking by, and several .jpg files that were 0 kb.  I know he was out there multiple times, and he saw several animals and that was it.  I'm still pretty happy with video mode, and very disappointed in the still mode.

Reviews.Title: Surveillance
Reviews.Author: Robert A. Staton
Reviews.Content: I'm using my camera for surveillance in a high crime area.  The worst thing I discovered is that the "invisible" IR flash is actually quite visible as dim red.  It doesn't really flash either.  It's more like they turn on for a couple of seconds.  I think the exposure time at night is roughly 1/30 to 1/5 sec.  So if your subject is moving, they will be blurry.  In day time the exposure is shorter, so,there's not much motion blur. At night, the pictures are all black and white, and the resolution seems to drop to about 1MP even though the image size is still 8MP.  Also beware the actual image sensor is 5MP, so the 8MP setting is basically a lie.  It does provide a better picture though, by virtue of a lower compression ratio.  I am impressed with the clarity of daytime photos, however.  They are far better than what a video camera produces, and very sharp all the way down to the pixel (at 5MP).  If I could ask for improvements, it would be to add more settings, and use longer wavelength LEDs that do not make an obvious red glow.

Reviews.Title: Yes / No Maybe So !!!!!
Reviews.Author: Lazer Fers
Reviews.Content: MIXED BAG:I won't start this by saying, "don't buy this item..it is junk!" I have mixed views on this Bushnell Camera. I am returning the item only because "my" camera was real junk, for sure. I had read hundreds of the reviews on Amazon, as well as, those on the internet dealing with these cameras. I have a great deal of experience with this Bushnell Cam, so I understood how to set the camera parameters up and how to use all the features, since they have the same buttons, etc. I bought this camera because it was the cheapest Bushnell that had the "non flash" PIR that allows for more sleath that won't scare away animals. My experience was using my brother's for nearly 3 months of daily use last year. I liked it so much I wanted one. This one has an 8 MP camera, which  took great clear photos on my brother's camera, and the videos were fantastic during the day/color recordings.You can see from the reviews, here at Amazon, most people got great results with their cameras. I was bothered by the fact that there were any bad reviews, except for possible DOA problems, since I had such a great experience with my brother's camera. I checked the internet out thoroughly on this camera and found that there were atrocious reviews as well. After reading hundreds it seemed that about 20% hated this camera and 80 % loved it. This is unofficial, but certainly left doubts in my mind. I hoped that I would get one of the good ones like my brother. I've never won the lottery, but I figured I could beat the odds, so I bought one of these. I lost the lottery, again! Dang!I installed the 8 batteries and the SD card, then used the MENU to format the card. Worked fine.I set the camera to the highest resolution, 8 MP, and the highest sensitivity so it would take photos even if a chipmunk walked by.I set the date and time and used the strap to attach to a tree facing my compost heap. I opened the console door in order to set it from the OFF to the ON mode. Three batteries fell out. My brother's battery compartment held them in tightly. What changed? The battery holders are weak and when attached verically to a tree they tend to fall out when you open the console door, which you have to do, if you want to turn it ON. No problem, next time I will put tape across all 8 batteries.I danced around during the light of a very bright day and left it there for hours. My wife later put some scraps in the compost. In the evening I went out to check out what the camera had taken. I was extremely disappointed. I found pictures of myself from 10 feet out, only. These were during a bright afternoon. All the other dancing around from 75 feet and inward, was in vain... the sensor never recorded anything passed 10 feet. But, the worst was the quality. Even though it was a very bright day, the pictures were nearly black with only my white shoes and faintly viewable face shining through the murkiness, and it was highly flushed with no definition. This could never record a chipmunk even if he were 3 feet tall. This was nothing like my brother's camera when I tried similar tests. During my research on the internet I found that this was the biggest complaint... really dark pictures and an inability to sense movement during the day. Maybe the camera needed a driver update????I did a search and found that the camera might, could, maybe, perhaps, need an update, but I'd never know because there is no way to check the version installed in the camera. All I could do is get the latest update and see if it improves things. I found the latest update for my model and installed it using the SD card, and was hopeful it would solve the problem. The camera accepted the update.  I lost the lottery, again. Dang!!!The daylight shots, in midday broad daylight were garbage... all washed out, and dark. I thought maybe the gain was wrong, so I put the photos in my image software and drove the gain up, brightness up, etc. It brightened the picture and at the same time washed it out. It was indeed a horrible picture to begin with and no software would fix it. The dusk and dawn pictures were not usable and at a bad resolution considering it was supposed to be 8 MP. The pictures are worse than the cheapest digital camera one could buy.Unfortunately, these dusk and dawn times are when many animals are most active.I tried the camera in video mode during the bright day. It was only able to record me moving around when I got within 12 feet of the camera. My brother's camera could pick me up during the day at over 40 feet. On top of that, the video was horrible by any video standard.... smeary, and dark.I tried the camera at night and it worked as expected, and did a great job at black and white photography even at long distances at night.I used the FieldScan which essentially takes pictures over and over at a given location at prescribed intervals. This feature worked, but with bad dark pictures, who cares???CONCLUSION:What I learned was that all these cameras, although they are advertised to be the same, are not. The cameras are made in China. I had, in the past, researched Chinese production methods. Like most companies around the world, Chinese companies purchase parts and circuit boards from numerous other companies to reduce costs and increase profits. All items, although advertised to be the same, are made from a hodge-podge of items from different vendors. The only problem with most Chinese companies is they have no quality control, so products are slapped together, assuming everything is fine, and then passed on to the consumer without regard, and left to the consumer to filter out the garbage. I became one of these filters with this product. This item was in no way comparable to the other Busnell camera of my brother's and could not be made to be, in the slightest, similar in quality. Externally, it was identical, but that is all.But, based on reviews at Amazon and other sources on the internet, it is possible to get a great Bushnell camera. My brother even has one.My ultimate conclusion is that you take your chances and join the lottery. They are in favor of a good camera, but don't be surprised if you get a bad one... it is possible. I am not the type to forgive or forget, so my personality says I will look somewhere else, unfortunately. Bushnell used to be a good optic brand for me.ONE GOOD THING:Thank goodness for Amazon's easy return policy... I couldn't live without it, and it is great business practice. At least, if you get one of the bad cameras, you can return it with very little hassle which I am doing right now.

Reviews.Title: Best on the market--versatile and inexpensive
Reviews.Author: G. G. Buckner "fe2manz"
Reviews.Content: These are good cameras. I have used hundreds of Trail Cams over the last 10 years--over 600 to be more precise. The Trophy Cam line has been the best performer by far. If you encounter short battery life, or too many or too few pictures, or pictures out of frame, I would advise changing your settings--As a wildlife biologist I use a variety of trail Cams, and these are by far the most versatile. I use them for everything from voles, to birds, to herps and large mammals.Just be prepared to spend a few days testing the settings--don't set it up for a week or two the 1st time and go back to see what happened. Also, I highly recommend the Ultimate Lithium batteries. They last a LOT longer--months longer than regular alkaline batteries. I have some high traffic areas that batteries last about 6 weeks in, but as I use high sensitivity on a number of cameras, I go through them pretty fast even in low traffic areas. Using Normal settings, 2 pics per shot, with a 10 second interval I get a good 6-11moonths out of a set of the UL batteries by Energizer. Just be sure that you don't have tall grasses or waving branches in the field of view--you will get thousands of pictures of plant life--not very exciting. Also, the camera does not "know" when the SD card is full so if you are in a high traffic area or using high sensitivity, it will continue to take pictures even though the card is full---wasting the batteries (another reason to test it out for a night or 2 in order to get the settings correct for your plans). I have had only a few problem cameras from Bushnell, and they warranteed me new ones immediately. I have had multiple other brands that have basically told me tough luck. You can find a simple camera or a  good camera--I vote for the good ones.

Reviews.Title: Great Cam for year round use
Reviews.Author: Susan Miller "SusieQ"
Reviews.Content: I'm not a hunter but I enjoy seeing the wild life that is in my area so I went out (more like went online) to find a good one that takes good pictures and functions well.  I decided upon this model after looking at a number of different ones.  For the price this one was one of the higher rated models.  Overall I am very pleased!  The quality of the videos that it takes and the photos are great and there are multiple settings for quality (megapixels, etc).It's easy to setup (keep it close to the ground for the best results.  Animals will notice if it's located to high).  As far as I can tell it's very quiet.  I certainly can't hear it snapping photos when I'm in front of it.  I've had this for a year now and have used it through all seasons without a problem.  The batteries last a good period of time even during the winter which is a huge plus!  Night vision works very well as well.  I like that you can change the sensitivity settings so if there is a lot grass, tree limbs in the photo it won't be snapping 4,000 photos every time the wind blows.Very easy to swap memory cards which is another huge plus!So far I have captured plenty of wildlife; Turkeys, deer, rodents, bear (make sure you dont have any feed/food scent on the cam or you will be sorry), coyotes, foxes, etc.Overall I couldn't be happier!I have noticed on rare occasion that when you open the device to get the memory card, the screen won't turn on.  Usually I just turn it off again and back on and it works.  Not a widespread issue so I can't really complain.  Thought I would mention it though.TIP: When swapping memory cards, make sure to format the card with the camera!  Just because you delete the photos from the card on the computer doesn't mean that the space is cleared.  For some reason the cam will still state that the space isn't free.  Always format then use.  I have posted some photos take with the 5 megapixel setting.

Reviews.Title: Good Trail Camera
Reviews.Author: J. Masiakos "Avid hunter - outdoorsman"
Reviews.Content: I was anxious to receive my new Bushnell Trophy Cam. It took about 5 mins to set it up. I put in 4 lithium ion AA batteries and I set it up in my backyard to test it out and I must say I was impressed with the photos. The videos were great too. I cannot wait to use it in the field this coming hunting season.Update. I've owned this trail camera for over a year. I have used one set of lithium ion batteries over the past year and it has taken literally thousands of pictures. I've upgraded my rating to 5 stars.

Reviews.Title: Too much fun
Reviews.Author: 10fish
Reviews.Content: I am having so much fun with this camera set up in my back yard.  In just a week, it has caught a fox, a skunk, a squirrel, a bear, a raccoon, a cat, and the next door neighbors' golden retriever.  Also, lots of pictures of me doing yard work. My neighbor caught a mountain lion on his last spring.  If you live in a place with wildlife, you should get one of these cameras, too!  It so far is working exactly as advertised.

Reviews.Title: chinese junk
Reviews.Author: Feral
Reviews.Content: I assumed Bushnell was a quality manufacturer, so when my first trophy cam started snapping pics every 5 seconds until the card was full, regardless of settings, I figured it was a fluke.  I purchased another trophy cam which, as before, worked great for the first few months.  Now, however, about half the pics are streaked with rainbow color, or so green, blue, or red tinted they are unusable.  FYI, my Primos trail cam (at less than half the price) is still performing very well, and actually provides better after dark pics.  Not all the bells and whistles, but very reliable.  I'll update when Bushnell customer service responds to my complaint.

Reviews.Title: Wow!!  I can't believe what's out there!
Reviews.Author: P. Cole
Reviews.Content: This little camera is great - we got it just for fun, but we were shocked with the photo of a mountain lion walking past our back porch about the third night we used it!!  (We live in a very rural area, not in a city.)  I used it most recently to photograph some very seldom seen migrating birds at our feeder to share with our local birding group.  The quality of the photos is great for "fun" stuff like Facebook.  And, although getting it set up and using it the first few times required careful reading of the instructions, I can now check the photos every day in just a few minutes - very easy and quick to do.If I had it to over, I probably would spring for the next $$ up which would have given me color photos at night (this one does color for day photos and black and white for night photos); it also would have allowed me to check photos right at the camera without needing to remove the SD card and take it to my computer.But, overall, for the price, this little camera is now one of our favorite Amazon purchases of all time -- we're constantly moving it to try it in new places to see what we find.

Reviews.Title: Great camera and my dog is very photogenic.
Reviews.Author: yote
Reviews.Content: I received the Trophy Cam 3 days ago.  Despite what some others have said in the reviews, setting it up was a breeze.  I read the entire manual that came with it.  It was very short and took about 15 minutes.  I popped in 8 new Energizers, a 2GB SD card, set the date/time and strapped it to a pole in my yard.  I poured a bucket of corn on the ground about 8 feet away.  I took the default settings for day one.Day1. When I got home, I could not wait to check my photos.  I pulled the SD card and popped it in my PC.  To my surprise there was my dog eating some of the corn.  According to the time stamp this was only 30 minutes after I left it there!  She made several more trips during the night ensuring I did not see anything interesting and the cam took photos every time.  Who knew that my dog who gets fed every morning and evenening would like dry shelled corn?  During the day, I had photos of my dog as well as crows, cardinals and blue jays.  On the birds I could only see the tops of their heads in many cases... had the bait too close to the camera!Day2. I adjusted the settings to my liking.  Set it up for taking 3 photos on each trigger, set the field scan to every 30 minutes, and to trigger only once per minute.  I moved the corn about 15 feet away from the cam.  When I got home yesterday, once again I had to check the camera first thing...could not wait!  Well you guessed it...during the night there was my dog eating corn again and this time with some of her neighborhood dog friends.  The other dogs did not eat the corn, but just kinda hung out.  I had about 100 dog photos, a couple of cats had wondered by, and three photos of one deer about 50 feet away that was almost out of the infrared flash range, but still very clear even if kind of dark.  I had one animal that blazed by so fast I could not make out what it was.  According to the manual, I could lower the resolution to 3MP to catch fast animals, but I'd rather have the bigger, better photos.  During the day yesterday I had crows, doves, cardinals and blue jays.  Once again it captured them without a hitch only this time I could see their whole bodies because they were at the better distance from the cam.  Also, thanks to the field scan I could see that nobody had came in my yard etc.  It's a great way to view a large area without requiring a trigger.Day3.  I cannot wait to get home!I hope this review helps someone.  It is my first field cam, so I cannot really compare it to any other model but I do LOVE it so far.  It is really neat and even with the default settings there was an animal in every triggered photo so I think it did a great job.  Can't wait to put it in the woods this week-end!***UPDATE***I've had the camera for almost 2 months now and it is still working great.  I have moved it into the woods.  I have captured deer, fox, racoon, squirrel, rabbit, cats, dogs, possum, birds etc.  If you get a lot of action, the batteries will not last as long as the product specifies...not even close.  You will get 3-4 weeks max.  Anyway, that's still good enough that I would not change my 5-star review.

Reviews.Title: Low sensitivity problem
Reviews.Author: E. Butler
Reviews.Content: The camera works okay on large subjects in daylight. However at night it completely fails to detect cat or fox-sized animals even at the modest distance of about 23-feet. It fails in this task even with its' sensitivity set at "High". Apparently the P.I.R. sensor used in this camera is not sensitive enough for use in small animal study except possibly at arms reach. This is disappointing since I chose this particular camera for its' infrared capabilities and the detection range it claims.Perhaps this product should be marketed as a "Deer Camera" rather than as a "Trail Camera" since it can't see the small guys very well at all.

Reviews.Title: TERRIBLE night time pics!
Reviews.Author: Chris Jarman
Reviews.Content: I have been a satisfied Cuddeback user for many years but I decided to try this camera because it had decent reviews.  Big mistake!  This camera takes excellent pics during the day, but is borderline useless at night.  I hope Amazon will take it back!  Don't waste your money on this camera. The only thing worse than this camera is the safe that I bought for it!

Reviews.Title: Fun
Reviews.Author: compnaut
Reviews.Content: Bought this to track animals passing through our yard at night. It has worked well and been a lot of fun. Amazed to see foxes passing through our front yard as well as deer. Camera has been easy to use and works as advertised. Also bought a Primos Truth cam 60. It has also worked okay. Prefer the smaller BUshnell simply due to its size. Primos takes pictures further away at night (has 60 LEDs) and has a slightly easier to use menu and controls. However, the primos is much larger, which makes it less convenient. For that reason, I prefer the Bushnell. That said, both have worked well.Put the camera out at night, bring it in and use USB cable to connect to PC to download the pictures from the camera. This works well at home, not sure what hunters do out in field without a built in viewer (this model cannot display pictures on the builtin LCD screen, just the menus.

Reviews.Title: Generally Pleased with this Trail Cam
Reviews.Author: TreeFarmer "TreeFarmer"
Reviews.Content: This is my first trail cam and I read so many reviews before ordering the Bushnell 8MP Trophy Cam and it seems like there is no "perfect" trail cam.  So far what I have found is that in low light conditions - morning and evening - the picture are somewhat dark.  The unit seems like it is in daylight mode when it should be in IR black-and-white mode.  But this has not been a big problem.The daytime pictures are nice and sharp!  Very cool to get a nice picture of the woods and fields and the animal.  The nighttime pictures are somewhat grainy, but I can get a good idea of the size of the deer and a good look at the rack on the bucks.  Besides deer, I have also "captured" a coyote and a raccoon!I have shot about 200 still photos so far and just switched the camera to video mode and will see how that works.  I liked this trail cam so well that I just ordered a second one.  Part of me wanted to try a different one to see if I could get something better in the same price range, but I didn't want to mess with that and maybe ending up sending it back (although Amazon makes that so easy) or have to learn the setup on a second camera.  Speaking of that, I was pleased with the Setup mode on the camera.  I used the documentation and just messed with the setup and was able to change settings and figure out how and what to change pretty easily.One last thing - I got two SD cards and when I go to check the camera, I just pull the one that's in there out and put the second one in.  Works great - only have to make one trip to the camera and I don't have to have my phone or laptop with me out in the woods.  I just keep rotating the cards as I take the pictures off of them.

Reviews.Title: GREAT CAMERA
Reviews.Author: kev
Reviews.Content: THIS CAMERA PROVIDES GREAT PICTURES AS WELL AS VIDEOS FROM ABOUT 50+ FEET. TAKES AWESOME NIGHT TIME PICTURES, PROVIDES MANY GREAT DETAILS. HAVEN'T FOUND ONE CRAPPY PICTURE YET AND I'VE GONE THROUGH OVER 8000 PICTURES OF DEER, BEARS, SQUIRRELS, AND MANY OTHER CREATURES FROM THE WOODS. SEALS TIGHT SO NO WATER WILL GET INTO THE CAMERA ITSELF. I DEFINITELY RECOMMEND THIS CAMERA...ITS WORTH EVERY PENNY!

Reviews.Title: poor construction and warranty
Reviews.Author: taxt
Reviews.Content: This is the second one like this I bought.  It worked ok at first but gradually has stopped working much at all.  The return window has expired, so it is just an expensive hunk of junk.  If it had not worked ok at first I'd have returned it then.  Be careful of this one.  Sometimes ok isn't worth the money or the hassle.

Reviews.Title: exceeds expectations
Reviews.Author: jcarter1033
Reviews.Content: This was my first trail camera I bought and I mainly wanted to use it to track the deer in my backyard. I set it up about 13 yards away from their path of travel and got excellent clear night time photos of a group of 4 doe.  Not only that, the 45' motion detector sensor is a far understatement.  This camera snapped tons of pictures of my neighbors vehicles as they drove up and down their driveway, over 40 yards away (on sensor mode not field scan). I use 8 batteries in the camera just because I figured it would give the flash and sensor a little more power instead of the suggested 4. This camera is going to my hunting location overseeing a large heavily traveled field and i'm confident it won't miss a thing.

Reviews.Title: Great Trail Cam for the Price
Reviews.Author: Marcia A.
Reviews.Content: I love this camera. I live in several acres and there are always tracks on the trails so I wondered what was passing through. This camera has captured some great images. The daytime quality is very good. They won't win awards, but they provide high resolution and good color so I can have a history of all the wildlife that has passed through. The nighttime photos are the typical black and white with little resolution for details, but you can still easily determine what the critter is. I set it to take one photo when the motion detector is tripped and then another shot 1 second later and a third 1 second after that. This seems to be a good setting for getting the most images. Often, the sensor trips before the subject is actually within lens range and this setting ensures I almost always get a shot of the animal. Since most of the animals are on the move, it may be just a nose that is within sensor range. The multiple shots option is great. Given the range of prices on cameras, you might be able to do better with the top-of-the-line at five or six hundred dollars, but I don't have that kind of cash. This price range is VERY reasonable for the quality of construction and photos it takes. The camera is definitely a 'keeper.'

Reviews.Title: Nice performance and value.
Reviews.Author: R. Rodrigues "Reggie"
Reviews.Content: I don't know much about trail cameras but my son (15) asked for one for Christmas. I did some research on-line and this is the one I settled for. So far it has performed well and we have not been disappointed. My son sets it up in a field near our house and so far we have captured videos of foxes, flying squirrels, one coyote, opossum and racoon.  Also crows and blue jays that come to our bait pile. I never had one of these before but I have been impressed by the quality of the images/videos. It has many settings for flexibility. I also bought a case and cable to secure it to the tree hoping to prevent somebody from walking away with it. You can easily connect it to your pc and copy the images/videos. The only thing I don't like is that the batteries don't seem to be fully seated in their slots. They seem to always be ready to fall out but we have not had any problems with them falling out during set up.01/18/12 Well, I had just posted this review and then found out that the camera stopped working. I now have to see what it takes to send it back.  I am totally bummed.03/02/12. Update on this review.  It turns out the camera was fine, it was the memory card that filled up and that is why the camera was not recording any longer. We continue to set the camera at night and have gotten nice videos of different animals near our house. I would certainly buy another one of these.

Reviews.Title: What stirs in the night......
Reviews.Author: Billy Hoglan
Reviews.Content: I bought this one for the wife.  She likes to see what animals come around at night.  We live in the County on acreage and have a varity of critters stop by for water and scraps of food. We have night time photos of Fox, Coons, Opossums, Deer and a number of cats that inconsiderate owners allow to roam. The day time photos of squirrels/birds/deer are great and I think it will make a good security camera when gone for a few days.  The night time photos are pretty good but if too close the flash washes the scene out some what.  It also makes the eyes of the animals glow.  I miss understood the model I ordered and it does not have a viewing screen for the photos.  We take the SD card out and view it on the TV or Computer.  No soft ware needed.  Download the ones we want. It uses 4-8 AA batteries and the menu is fairly simple.  However I am unable to get it to erase the SD card in the unit.  Which it is suppose to do.  A simple 2g SD card will hold thousands of pictures. Have not used the video function yet.

Reviews.Title: Very good cam
Reviews.Author: Rich
Reviews.Content: This camera is easy to use...great battery life...great pics (day and night). I use a 4G mini SD card so I can look at the pics in the field with my cell phone...works well for me. Good reaction time and held up to the wet weather just fine. Only negatives (minor) are it could have a better hanging strap and wish it had memory to keep the date/time when I change batteries. I recommend this camera...it's worth the money in my opinion.

Reviews.Title: Great camera for game or general surveillance
Reviews.Author: John "H"
Reviews.Content: This is the second unit I am purchasing. The first is still in service, in fact I just changed the batteries after 14 months. One isn't really enough to observe the amount of deer traffic I encounter. I've used the game cam to watch over my hunting cabin too. The performance is outstanding and captures great images night or day. Night closeups do wash out from the flash and the unit will trigger on moving brush if the sun is in the direction of the view. I would expect that anything IR is going to do that. Using a 4gb card, I get a ton of photos and have never filled a card, even after months of use. The power switch is a little unprecise, but works so far. Resolution is decent and the videos clips are pretty exciting sometimes. Glad I got the ones without the viewer built in. I didn't need that added expense, but the card slips right in my camera for easy previews anyway. I'd love to have a half dozen of these babies, but for now I'll settle for two.

Reviews.Title: Don't buy!
Reviews.Author: Greg K. Spigarelli
Reviews.Content: This camera takes lousy pictures at night and during twilight the camera takes dark pics.I called bushnell Tech support and they said the camera must have a bad light sensor and they would replace it, to send in the old one.  I did and got another unit.  I upgraded the firmware and set the "Field Scan" feature on to record the twilight morning period in my area at one minute intervals for two hours total.  The camera takes poor quality night shots and when the sun starts coming up it takes better black and white shots until the camera switches over to color and they are very dark for the next 20 minutes or so.  I think the firmware needs upgrading to allow for these conditions.  If I run the pictures thru a program like Microsoft Office picture viewer I can use the auto correction feature on the pictures to make them viewable. The great battery life only creates problems for the night time picture quality.  I have an older Cuddyback NoFlash that is superior to the Bushnell.The only good feature is the price, $155.00 @ Amazon.

Reviews.Title: Bushnell 8MP Trophy Cam Brown Night Vision Trail Camera
Reviews.Author: Tom C
Reviews.Content: This is the first trail camera I ever owned.  Purchased the camera in July and it has worked flawlessly since day one. It's used at home as a security camera with an external power supply and a 16GB SanDisk for external storage.  It's taken over 1800 pics at home.  It is also used at our mountain home on a feeder with the batteries powering the camera.  Over 400 pics were taken with LITHIUM batteries (8) and the battery indicator on the camera still shows full.  This is a really good camera that takes great pics and video.

Reviews.Title: OVERATED
Reviews.Author: C Nations
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera based on the reviews here. Seemed to have gotten better than average score. The day I received it, I mounted it on the same tree as a $50 Tasco so I could compare photos. I gave it a day and half, then retrieved the cards and popped them in the computer....The Tasco took 9 pictures, 8 of which were deer. The Bushnell took 2300 pictures!! Only 4 deer!! Very poor nightime, as well as the dawn transition. Alot of nothing! Would not recommend. Very disappointed.

Reviews.Title: Great value
Reviews.Author: Joe Pelosi "Harry Biden"
Reviews.Content: Great value.  If there is a defective camera send it back, but that could happen with any brand.The photo quality and sensitivity is as good or better than models that cost 2-3x more!Buy through Amazon and do not look back!This is great fun, around the house or on your hunting property. It's a great way to scout year round if you have a day job :)

Reviews.Title: Great Trail Cam
Reviews.Author: bwanc
Reviews.Content: I've reviewed the other reviews and don't know why so many people are having problems.  This camera (Bone Collector model) has worked great for me.  Setup was easy.  I added a security box and cable.  During my initial placement, I made the mistake of aiming the camera in the direction of the afternoon sun.  That made my afternoon pictures black.  My nighttime pictures were perfect.  After I moved the camera away from the afternoon sun, my daytime pictures were just as great.  I recommend getting two SD cards, so when you go to retrieve one, you can immediately place a new one.  It saves a trip. I have had my camera running for approximately four months and the battery is still strong.  The camera has taken over 3,000 pictures of deer, squirrel, turkey, fox, and raccoons. If I have an empty shot, it is sure to be followed in the next 1-3 frames by an animal.  Because of the date/time stamps on the pictures and the quality of pics I was getting, I was able to identify and land a beautiful 8 pointer before the end of the season.  I highly recommend this camera.

Reviews.Title: This works very well
Reviews.Author: Pat
Reviews.Content: This item has worked very well for us. We have been able to see many more animals than previously due to the infrared flash and the quiet operation. We have pictures of deer faces only inches from the lens, looking right into it. Our old one had a visible flash that frightened the animals and made them skiddish. The pictures are very clear, both day and night. We have utilized this for a month now with no problems and are recommending it to ours.

Reviews.Title: My first trail camera
Reviews.Author: jj
Reviews.Content: I looked at 15 different brands and decided on Bushnell.  I wanted small size, AA battery operation, fast trigger, long battery life, IR flash, good price, and good detection distance.  This camera easily meets those requirements after testing it for several days.  I measured the battery current draw and it should operate as long as advertised.  The construction is excellent and its setup is simple and very flexible.  This is my first camera and other brands might also be good but I am certainly happy with Bushnell.  This one cost more than some others I considered but it is well worth it.

Reviews.Title: Great Little Trail Cam
Reviews.Author: Lauren C
Reviews.Content: Love the camera and the price. I now have two. Pictures and Videos are excellent and the new of sound feature was a great addition. When setting up for the first time, remember to save the setting after each selection. I use the low sensitivity setting to avoid too many false positive recordings caused by light wind motion. Camera will work with 4 or 8 AA batteries which lets you change sets without loosing settings - just replace one bank at a time. Battery life is great even with 30 sec. video and sound. I use "enloope" rechargeable batteries and they last for the full season (October to January)& more without recharging. The "infrared" light (red glow) does not bother deer. They may notice it but do not spook at all. I would recommend this product to anyone wanting to get pictures of wild life. I have video of deer, bobcat, raccoon, hunters, and more. I also purchased the metal case and python lock because I hunt public / state lands.

Reviews.Title: Bushnell 8MP Trophy Cam
Reviews.Author: Night Rider
Reviews.Content: Have been using this camera in the rain and snow for three weeks now. Temps have been as low as 20 degrees F. and camera has worked without a problem. Night pics are clear with a range of about 50 ft. Daylight pics are clear, crisp with a sensor range of around 50 ft. Manual was an easy read and set up was just as easy. Am thinking about purchasing another one for security purposes.

Reviews.Title: I got the lst one in Nov..
Reviews.Author: Rosalie Tuttle
Reviews.Content: I got the lst one in Nov.. It quit working after one week.. Sent it back...Got a replacement for the lst camera and after 3 days it quit working.. The lst 2 day's it took over 302 pics of deer.. This AM brought it in it had 3 pictures.. I seen deer out there all night long should have had 200+ on it.. Sending it back for refund..

Reviews.Title: It works!
Reviews.Author: Meesh
Reviews.Content: This game cam is easy to setup, it works well, and it's reasonably priced.  I like it and will be buying another one.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera at a Great Price
Reviews.Author: wendyinlb
Reviews.Content: I bought the Bushnell camera based on recommendations from others.  I'm happy with it. It's easy to use and takes great quality pictures.  The camera range and motion detection feature is pretty impressive.  It's also quiet and the flash is barely noticeable.  For $200, it's a great buy.  I bought this to use as a surveillance camera and am thinking of buying another.  These are easier to install than a video system with DVR, and since they run on batteries there's no need to rely on electricity or a wireless router.

Reviews.Title: Do yourself a favor and get this
Reviews.Author: Scotfrommo
Reviews.Content: I have tried many cams and this is the best I have everhad.  I had an earlier  version and the only complaint was the strap it came with.They have a better strap now and I have no complaints.I have heard Recoynx are better, but at least 400 this is175ish get this one.

Reviews.Title: Displeased
Reviews.Author: Richard Smith
Reviews.Content: Did not like the camera at all. Returned it after one day's use. The pictures were terribleboth in daytime and night. Would not recommend this camera to anyone.

Reviews.Title: Buyer Beware
Reviews.Author: TJ
Reviews.Content: I had nothing but problems with the Trophy Cam. I sent the first one back after waiting on the phone for customer support for about 45 minutes. The one I sent back was camo and they sent me a completely brown one. After about 6 months of the second camera that too quit working on me. I am all done with Trophy Cam. I didnt even bother sending the second one back. I was so mad I smashed it on the cement. The seal quickly deteriorates and water gets inside. Go get the Moultrie M80x. Cheaper and the IR is better.

Reviews.Title: Smile you are on candid camera
Reviews.Author: Dan "Top laid back"
Reviews.Content: I bought this as a security camera for my home. I was going through a divorce and the soon to be ex has some boys that are trouble. Secured it in drab colored metal box with a Python locking cable outside on my carport support column.Also put up the fake security camera and a Svat video protection sign on the other side of the carport to draw attention away from the trail camera which I probably did not need as it is not over noticeable.Mounted it about chest high and it covers pretty much the front lawn of my average sized lot day and night. During the day it records all the traffic in the neighborhood and at night the same The first time I pulled the memory disk and downloaded I was amazed to see all traffic coming and going. You would see neighbors arriving home, the postman delivering etc.Luckily I live in a lightly travelled neighborhood.But it works. What impressed is that there was some kids coming into neighborhoods and breaking into carsIt caught them walking in the street which was about a 75 foot shot and when they came into my drive way Smile you are on candid camera. Gave the disk to the police and now there are three teenagers who are not walking the streets.

Reviews.Title: Good choice for trailcam
Reviews.Author: A. Morgan
Reviews.Content: The picture quality on this camera is great.  I can't compare it to several others, because I don't have several other trailcams, but I was very impressed with the color quality, resolution, and just general look to the pictures taken by the camera.  Its small, lightweight, and easy to get set up and running.I have two problems with the product.  1) There's no way to view the pictures on the device.  There is a little LCD screen inside, but its only for applying configuration settings, etc.  Its not a big deal, but it would be nice to be able to get a quick look at what ws captured and just delete pictures that aren't interesting right there without having to bring the SD card back to the house or cabin.  2) The bigger problem is in the way the files are named.  Let's say it takes 10 pictures, it names them something like "img0001" to "img0002" (not the actual name, but the indexing is the point).  The problem is, say you copy the pictures onto your computer or tablet and delete them off the trailcam.  When the camera starts taking pictures again it starts back over at 1, so the new image is called "img0001" again.  If you want to copy that picture onto your computer or tablet too, then you either have to rename it or put it in a separate directory since the names are identical.  I'm not sure how big a problem this is for some people, but this camera was a gift for my father who isn't very technologically advanced, and this adds a level of complexity to managing the pictures that is just unnecessary.All in all though, a strong 4 stars - if it wasn't for the file naming thing, it would be a 5 star trailcam.

Reviews.Title: Bushnell Trophy Cam
Reviews.Author: Old Timer "Old Timer"
Reviews.Content: I have four of the 2009 models which have some special features that are no longer offered. The 2010 models had too many problems and gave the product a bad name.  I bought one 2011 model a year ago and they seem to have corrected the major problems of 2010.  I was satisfied  enough that I bought another 2011 model and so far have been satisfied.  There isn't enough game present right now to make much of a test.  I did learn to appreciate the audio function.  My hunters have learned to stop at the camera and give a hunting report!

Reviews.Title: Bushnell 8mp
Reviews.Author: Roger Kaput
Reviews.Content: Seams to be a great camera. Had it set in the front yard to test while gone on vacation and had 180 pictures in one week.  Most were the peolpe watching the house ( at least now we know they came by), but did get some deer and the neighbors dog. good trigger speed, night quality is ok, daytime quality is great. Thingk I may get one or two more as it seams to be  great value.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: Smithman
Reviews.Content: I made the mistake of going for a cheaper priced camera,  needless to say i returned the cheaper camera less than a week later.  Purchased the Bushnell 8mp trail camera and was amazed at how much better quality this camera is.  I used the lithium  batteries like the manufacturer said and still have full power after 1500 pictures taken.  Picture quality is great both day and night.

Reviews.Title: Works well, lacks a few frills but very reliable
Reviews.Author: der Teufel
Reviews.Content: This is the third game camera I have purchased. My first one was quite cheap, white flash (no IR), no video, and no selectable options. You got three photos each time it triggered and that was it. The second cost a bit more, but still <$100, and took video as well as still photos. Time delays and number or photos was selectable. However, it ate batteries and died constantly, seldom running as long as two weeks before croaking.I paid more for this Bushnell than the other two combined, but it takes good photos and excellent video. It even records sound with the video. That's not been a big deal yet but might be interesting some day. The main positive is that it works! It has good battery life and simply does what it is supposed to do. I wish it would record temperature and moon phase, but it doesn't. That is the only reason I rated it four stars instead of five. Still, it keeps taking pictures and that's what is most important to me.I haven't tried the Field Scan Mode, but I will. I think it might come in handy some time when I'm out for a few days at a time and want to know what's going on. I like the camera's small size, it is quite compact. I tried it on 5Mpix mode and the pictures were certainly good enough. I took video in higher resolution, wide-screen mode and I was very satisfied.If it allowed for customizing a name to be superimposed on the photos, along with including the ambient temperature and the moon phase, it would be perfect. As things are it is good enough. If I buy another camera, I'll strongly consider another Bushnell.

Reviews.Title: Nice little camera
Reviews.Author: Greatoutdoors
Reviews.Content: In past few weeks, this little camera has got some very nice pictures and videos. Documentation has been useful and accurate, enabling me to make the camera do what I wanted in all cases except 1 - still having a problem working out time between shots, perhaps it is me. Image does wash out if less than 10 feet to subject, as doc says. Sensitivity range great - way more than 100 feet. A bit of a delay between trigger and start of video. Nice color during daytime too. In short, it is doing what I bought it for, very well.

Reviews.Title: I like it
Reviews.Author: NYHunter
Reviews.Content: I like the size, price and reliability. It has everything I need and nothing I don't. I don't get alot of wasted pics of squirrels and small animals, yet I get pics of turkey, deer, fox and such. Batteries lasted at least 6 months so far.

Reviews.Title: Not Pleased at all
Reviews.Author: Matt1234
Reviews.Content: At first i was really pleased with the Camera.  I own three of the trophy cam HD models,  the first was infested by ants, which accessed the camera through the external battery plug in the bottm, the plug does not fit in the camera snuggly and falls out.  I noticed this on the other cameras as well.  The second camera  resets the date back to the default after one day.  It throughs the time off as well, leaving the field scan useless, as well as not having an accutate time stamp on the pictures.  Bushnells customer service will cover the issues, but they require you to pay all of the shipping.  I can understand having issues with cameras,  but when 66% of mine fail in the first 7 months of use, that is pretty bad. the third is starting to have issues as well( not taking picutes well within is detection circuit).  I wouldnt be so pissed off, but the fact that i have to pay to get their faulty products repaired is unreal.  I would stongly advise agianst getting these cameras.  I have had it with cheap cameras and I am going to spring for some Reconyx's. I figure it will save me money in the end.

Reviews.Title: Junk
Reviews.Author: PONDER
Reviews.Content: On my 2nd one of these cameras and it just crapped out. Warranty just run out also.  I'm finished with bushnell products.

Reviews.Title: Hard to use and never took pictures
Reviews.Author: chi
Reviews.Content: It just never worked. I bought this to see deer in my woods and field. I set it up for night operation and all I got was graininess withouteven a shadow of an image. Complete waste of money...too bad, it was expensive

Reviews.Title: Great Trail Camera
Reviews.Author: Steve Roll
Reviews.Content: This is my best trail cam.It's smaller then my overs.It takes great pictures.The battery life is spectacular.I have taken over 2600 pictures in six months and the batteries are still going strong.

Reviews.Title: great camera
Reviews.Author: phil
Reviews.Content: Have two of these cameras.  They take excellent pictures both during the day and night.  One common flaw or issue that are associated with this particular years model is the need to go to the Bushnell web site and do a software up date.  About a 6 weeks ago I had a issue with one of the cameras where it wasnt working anymore.  Contacted Bushnell and they walked me thru the process of sending it back (their warranty process).  They told me it would be up to 4 weeks or so to get it back since we were in the middle of the deer season.  Was surprise when a week later I had a new one.  If they cannot fix it they automatically send you a new one.  Calling to inquire what was wrong with the old it was a seal that had failed.  This warranty is good for up to two years.  Cant beat that.  I also recommend the Master Lock 8417D Python Adjustable Locking Cable, 6-Foot to lock it to the tree.  It fits perfectly thru the hole and back side as well gives enough extra slack to secure to the tree.  Good luck

Reviews.Title: SURPRISED!!!!
Reviews.Author: Shanna M. Romo
Reviews.Content: We put this in our front yard to perhaps catch some javalina coming through, but we snag some kids toilet papering our house instead. LOVE IT!

Reviews.Title: Washed out photos on bright days
Reviews.Author: AZRLS
Reviews.Content: Good news: Solid construction, the batteries last a long time, lots of useful setup options, and easy to use.Bad news: The photos taken in full light are badly washed out. Bushnell insists it is because sunlight is falling on the front of the camera, but absolutely all of the photos were taken with the camera facing away from the sun, so it has to be a fault in the camera. Kind of useless camera, actually.

Reviews.Title: Best camera for the money hands down.
Reviews.Author: Beam Me Up Scotty
Reviews.Content: Battery life, battery life, battery life. I've had two of these for a year and I just changed the batteries. I've got over 10,000 pics on each camera in every type of weather from 5 below zero to 90 degrees, rain, snow, sleet it never fails. Best value on the market. Picture quality is awesome, night pictures are awesome as well. The infrared flash does spook some deer at first but they get used to it.

Reviews.Title: Awesome battery life!
Reviews.Author: Ben
Reviews.Content: I live in northern Wiscobsim where temps hit negative digits. I put this camera out in September until late December last year and never had to Change batteries. Never have I had another camera able to make it through the late season without changing batteries.

Reviews.Title: Generally a fair camera, but 1 major problem.
Reviews.Author: JackieTH
Reviews.Content: I've used the Bushnell Standard Trophy cam for several years now, I bought it when it first came out.  Generally it's still passable (by 2013 standards) in terms of photo quality and sensitivity, the menu is just adequate although straightforward in execution.  It's low profile, compact, and blends in well with the environment.  I use it three or four times a year for a couple weeks at a time and the batteries (usually) last the entire time.  So, a 3.5/5 star device except for one serious problem that started about a year and a half ago, that seems to occur randomly, or possibly temperature related.  Every once in a while the camera goes haywire and continuously takes photos every minute or so, either until the batteries run out, or the memory card is full.  It can work for a several days or a week snapping pictures of game, then there are 1,500 photos of the empty field every minute, three at a time with a full card or dead batteries ending the shooting spree.  Seems to occur more often when the temps are below 35F.  Anyway, it's irritating and I won't be getting another Bushnell.

Reviews.Title: Consider these cameras disposable
Reviews.Author: NoSpam
Reviews.Content: I've had 6 of these, purchased over 3 years, in continuous outdoor operation.  They have all worked exceptionally, with one major defect that will eventually kill them all.  One has already failed and a second camera is well on it's way.The soft rubber door gaskets are not sold by Bushnell.  They eventually become hard or cracked and then fail, letting water into the camera and destroying it.As these are all made in China, it seems that no real spare parts are available.  Wasted time on the phone with them and they seemed to have no idea on how to get simple spare parts such as the rubber o-ring.So figure a life span of 3-4 years and then it's a throw away.

Reviews.Title: Great camera for backyard wildlife watching
Reviews.Author: reindeer
Reviews.Content: We've had this camera for about 2 months or so now and have used it more or less continuously in our backyard. The images during daylight hours are clear and in focus. During nighttime the images are black and white due to the infrared sensor, as if looking through nightvision goggles. They are not magazine quality wildlife images but it is possible to ID any critter that wanders in front of the camera, which is what we were interested in. The range is quite good, our camera captured animals that were about 20 yards or so from the camera, even at night. There is no sound from the camera that I could detect when it is taking pictures and the only visual signal is a weak red light from the infrared detector. Animals don't seem to be bothered by it in any way, based on the pictures we saw. It's certainly been fun to see what walks through the yard at times when we are not there or asleep. The reason that I am giving this four instead of five stars is mainly due to some design flaws that really should be fixed. (1) The batteries are not very firmly held in place and can be easily jostled when closing the camera case. There is no indicator that clearly tells you that the camera is working once the case is closed. You can step in front of it and look for the dim red light from the detector, but it's not foolproof. That means that you may come back to check your images and find that the camera was not actually on. Not such a big problem for us but not so good if you want to leave the camera for an extended time somewhere and come back after a month or so and there are no pictures. It helps to tape the batteries down. (2) There is no easy way to check that the camera is capturing the field you want it to. You have to set it up, walk in front of it, maybe at different distances, then take out the memory card, check the images and check if this is what you wanted to see. This can be time-consuming until you have it right and really depends on the area and what kind of critters you expect to see.I have never used any other trail camera so I don't know if other manufacturers have addressed these issues but overall I would recommend this camera and did not regret buying it at all.

Reviews.Title: Our second Bushnell Trophy Cam
Reviews.Author: femme du nord
Reviews.Content: We use these cams at our cabin in northern MN and have captured many interesting animals.  The colors are true and the camera batteries last a very long time - even in the winter.  Adjusting the settings requires a learning curve with a lot of fiddling around with the buttons so I only gave it 4 stars, but after playing around with different settings for sensitivity, resolution, number of shots in succession and interval between shots etc. I was able to get the right settings for the area.  Be aware, the sensitive setting will take a picture of the slightest leaf movement or several thousand photos of falling snowflakes, so a normal setting is recommended for most areas.  I also found I captured more images of wildlife if I used a setting of more than one photo in succession.  Battery life was very good, even in the colder weather.

Reviews.Title: For specialzed use only
Reviews.Author: Tom XYZ
Reviews.Content: Only triggers with large animals under ideal conditions. Cryptic, difficult to use programming interface. Requires 8 batteries, lithium recommended. Night time use emits bright red light revealing location. Limited mounting options - flimsy strap, or tripod socket which interferes with aux power plug on bottom of case.

Reviews.Title: It was dead on arrival
Reviews.Author: R. H. Tulis
Reviews.Content: I do not know what's going on with Bushnell - this was to be my second game camera (identical to my first).  When they work, they perform as advertised and I couldn't be happier.  The trick apparently is to figure out how to keep them working.The first one was replaced by Bushnell.  I used the replacement for a few months and then it failed to go into Setup Mode.  Returned it to Bushnell and they replaced it.  The 2nd replacement sat on the shelf for several months.  When I attempted to put it into use, I experienced the same problem.  I'm awaiting replacement of that one from Bushnell (which would be my 3rd).In the interim, I ordered a second one from Amazon - it arrived this afternoon.  I put fresh batteries in it, along with a brand new SD card - it also refuses to go into Setup Mode.  After a conversation with Bushnell, they indicated they would make good on it.  We will see - I will leave additional feedback when the replacement arrives.Apparently the Chinese have yet to learn how to do Quality Control.[Update 15 May 2013]  One missing piece of information in the User Manual for this product is that it is NOT an "Instant On" device.  It apparently takes a while to 'boot up'.

Reviews.Title: Money well spent
Reviews.Author: Mary Bishop
Reviews.Content: We are wildlife rehabilitators and did a "soft release" of five raccoons we'd raised from infancy on our wooded land last fall. Since we bought this trail cam and installed it near our feeding station, we have had so much fun seeing what the raccoons have been doing since then. We've counted seven raccoons, so our five have found some little friends! We've also seen two coyotes, some possums, a squirrel and a couple of neighbors' dogs. It's now "baby season" in the wildlife world, so we're looking forward to seeing some offspring from those we released last year.The camera is easy to use and has options for still photos or video, along with interval length. It provides black & white images lit by an infrared light at night and color pictures during the day. It comes with a strap to attach it to a tree or other object, so it's easy to move from place to place. We're loving it!

Reviews.Title: camera is fine
Reviews.Author: Patricia J Minsloff
Reviews.Content: My problem with this camera is the way the batteries fit. The results from the first few tries were spotty. When it worked, it was great but sometimes I captured no images at all so I thought I must be doing something wrong.  I discovered that the batteries tend to bulge out of place with very little provocation. Once the camera is in place, the last step before you turn it on must be to recheck the batteries to see if they are snugly in position.

Reviews.Title: Bushnell 8MP Trophy Cam Standard Edition 2011 model
Reviews.Author: Hulyn
Reviews.Content: Takes great pics, battery life good....BUT batteries pop out all the time. Get my camera in & the clock is back to 01/01/2011, time off too.Several times I've set it, got the camera..no pics, batteries out of connections & all the bait is gone. Should have had alot of pics.When it works, it is great, good pics, clear & sharp at night, but too many times screwing up because of loose batteries connections. (batteries DO NOT stay seated in connections, slide out just enough to lose contact.)Wish I would have gotten the Primos.....almost half the price, takes 2 D batt, not 4-8 AA like this one.

Reviews.Title: Nice camera
Reviews.Author: Dawna Feldpausch
Reviews.Content: This has been a good purchase.  It has taken some nice pictures and videos of deer/fox/coyote and even our dog!  The battery life has been very good!

Reviews.Title: Fails in low light
Reviews.Author: Bruce in Michigan
Reviews.Content: I have several other brand trail cams so I'm not a novice in this respect. Always looking for something a little better so I opted to try the trophy cam as it was on sale and I had read some good reviews. First the good; small, user friendly, nice middle of the day pics and nice middle of the nite pics. Now the bad; 1 1/2 hour before dark and the first 1 1/2 hrs of daylight  terrible almost all black or too dark to see pics. Additionally all my other trail cam models I can view my pics by putting the SD card into my easy share digital camera. The bushnell trail cam is not compatable and dosent view in my digital cam. I did call bushnell customer service and pretty much got, "it is what it is" or "your aiming the camera in the wrong direction."  What I was VERY satisfied with was Amazons easy return policy. Thank you Amazon.

Reviews.Title: Trophy cam standard edition by Bushnell
Reviews.Author: Bow hunter,Upstate,NY
Reviews.Content: Arrived inoperative, said it is brown, but actually it is black. A lot of money for a substandard product. It is better to go for a more expensive and reliable Bushnell Trail Camera.

Reviews.Title: Compact size and long battery life.
Reviews.Author: rdnick
Reviews.Content: I bought 2 of these and they are the first trail cameras that I have used so I can't compare them to other brands. I have had them for almost a year nowand I like the compact size, available features, photo quality and long battery life. I would have given the product 5 stars except the display on one of my cameras failed after about eight months and it had to be replaced by Bushnell. I was disappointed by the failure, but I understand that electronics fail sometimes and will say that the customer service from the Bushnell factory was good.
